backend.src.app.controllers.employees package

Submodules

backend.src.app.controllers.employees.employee_controller module

class backend.src.app.controllers.employees.employee_controller.EmployeeController(employee_id, update_data=None)[source]

Bases: object

The EmployeeController class provides methods for managing employee data.

This class acts as a controller for validating, updating, deleting, and preparing responses related to an employee.

Variables:

  • employee_id – The ID of the employee.

  • update_data – The data to update for the employee.

  • employee_service – An instance of the EmployeeService class for managing employee data.

create_response_with_employee_profile_data()[source]

Create a response containing all data about the employee.

This method uses the employee service to retrieve all data about the employee and prepares a response.

Returns:

A dictionary containing all data about the employee and HTTP status code of 200.

Return type:

tuple[dict[str, any], int]

create_response_with_successful_delete_message()[source]

Create a response with a successful delete message.

Returns:

A dictionary containing a success message and HTTP status code of 200.

Return type:

tuple[dict[str, str], int]

create_response_with_successful_update_message()[source]

Create a response with a successful update message.

Returns:

A dictionary containing a success message and HTTP status code of 200.

Return type:

tuple[dict[str, str], int]

delete_employee()[source]

Delete the employee.

This method uses the employee service to delete the employee based on their ID.

update_employee()[source]

Update the employee’s data.

This method uses the employee service to update the employee’s data. If the update data is invalid, it raises a ControllerException.

Raises:

ControllerException – If the employee update data is invalid. HTTP status code 400.

validate_employee()[source]

Validate the employee’s existence.

This method uses the employee service to validate the existence of the employee based on their ID. If the employee does not exist, it raises a ControllerException.

Raises:

ControllerException – If the employee does not exist. HTTP status code 404.

backend.src.app.controllers.employees.employees_controller module

class backend.src.app.controllers.employees.employees_controller.EmployeesController(employee_data=None)[source]

Bases: object

The EmployeesController class provides methods for handling employee-related requests.

This class acts as a controller that uses the EmployeesService for creating a new employee and preparing data related to all employees.

Variables:

  • employee_data – The data for creating a new employee.

  • employees_service – An instance of the EmployeesService class for managing employees’ data.

create_employee()[source]

Create a new employee.

This method uses the employees service to create a new employee with the provided data. If the employee data is invalid, it raises a ControllerException.

Raises:

ControllerException – If the employee data is invalid with HTTP code 400.

create_response_with_employees_data()[source]

Prepare a response containing data about all employees.

This method uses the employees service to retrieve data about all employees.

Returns:

A tuple where the first item is a list of data about all employees and the second item is the HTTP status code 200.

Return type:

tuple[list[dict[str, any]], int]

create_response_with_successful_create_message()[source]

Prepare a response containing a success message for employee creation.

Returns:

A tuple where the first item is a dictionary containing a success message and the second item is the HTTP status code 200.

Return type:

tuple[dict[str, str], int]

backend.src.app.controllers.employees.employees_sort_controller module

class backend.src.app.controllers.employees.employees_sort_controller.EmployeesSortController(sort_data)[source]

Bases: object

The EmployeesSortController class provides methods for sorting employees and creating an appropriate response.

This class acts as a controller for handling requests related to sorting employees.

Variables:

  • sort_data – The data specifying how employees should be sorted.

  • sorted_employees – The sorted employee data.

create_response_with_sorted_employees_data()[source]

Create a response containing the sorted employee data.

This method prepares a response with the sorted employee data. The response includes a 200 status code.

Returns:

The response containing the sorted employee data and a 200 status code.

Return type:

tuple[list[dict[str, any]], int]

sort_employees()[source]

Sort employee data based on the provided parameters.

This method uses the EmployeesSortService to sort all employees based on the sorting data. If the sorting fails, it raises a ControllerException.

Raises:

ControllerException – If the sorting fails due to invalid sort QUERY parameters.
